ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a good deal about rocks.
I gained practical knowledge of methods used in geology. As the course title implies, it's a survey into the major concepts used in the field.

This class was a great intro to field geology and making relevant observations when outdoors! It's very cool to now understand a practical level of Connecticut's geology. We learned a lot especially about identifying igneous rocks and their composition.
More advanced knowledge about minerals, rocks, and geology in general.

This course developed an extensive understanding of New England geology, the ability to conceptualize past geological environments based on present-day observations on the scale of millions of years, and gave a hands-on application of processes and vocabulary from lectures with the ability to identify the rock type by its physical characteristics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The field trip over fall break was absolutely the highlight of the course, you should definitely attend if you can.

Strengths: Really engaging lab that is not that much work! Without the lab, I don't think I would've taken away that much from the class, but I was able to see the lectures come to life on the field trips. 
Weaknesses: Deadlines were pretty confusing and it was pretty freeform which I guess wasn't the worst

This was a perfectly designed lab class. Professor Evans makes sure that the class is truly only half a credit's worth of work. Even though we only met for about 7 sessions, I still feel like I gained an adequate sense of the skills used in the field.

This course was great! I really enjoyed the field trips and how much practical knowledge was shared. It was fantastic to get outside in Connecticut and see actual examples of what we learned in lecture. THIS CLASS IS ACTUALLY A HALF-CREDIT STEM LAB :)). In the future, I would request that Professor Evans gives students a heads up about field trips that involve hiking so students with physical challenges/disabilities can prepare. Several of us were caught off-guard by the glacial features field trip in particular. In this vein, finding course information on Canvas was a little rocky. There wasn't too much detail in the syllabus.
Strengths: All three field trips are so interesting! Prof Evans and both TFs (James and Zheng) are very nice, patient, and knowledgable.

The strengths of the course were that the workload and the effectiveness of labs in helping with sustained exposure of concepts that aided greatly in recall of information. The field trips were great.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want to learn more about rocks, yeah. Definitely should take it if you're taking EPS 110, it adds a lot to the course.
YES! If you are taking EPS 110 I highly recommend taking the lab alongside!

Absolutely, especially if you're taking EPS 110, the companion lecture course! The themes in the class only really make sense (and get interesting) when you apply them directly. The highlight of the course (and really my entire semester) was the fall break trip across New England. The sights were gorgeous, and I am really proud of the work I did over the course of those few days.
I would absolutely recommend this course -- it's engaging, not too hard, and you learn a lot without really realizing it because the work is enjoyable.

I would highly recommend this lab to another student because information is conveyed concisely and understandably, the lab work greatly solidified concepts, and the class environment was comfortable and inclusive.
